Summary: unusual light in the sky, mostly steady, towards West, slightly above Pikes Peak skyline
divs: sighting detailsi hiked with a friend in the ute valley park (in colorado springs). at h17:40 mst +\- 10min, we were returning and coming out of the park, back at the beginning of the trail, after a 2hrs round trip hike. the trail here appears as a dirt road, getting into the park from mule deer drive. the way we were coming out of the park, this section of the trail (a couple of hundred yards), goes relatively steeply downhill, facing west and pikes peak. we were admiring the sunset sky and the beautiful view next to home. despite the cold, the day has been nice and sunny, then it turned overcast later and we were glad we got out for a hike. as we were coming down this last section of the trail, i noticed a strange light, appearing approximately as a horizontal segment of light, against the evening sky, just above the saddle to the south, in the skyline of pikes peak. i hiked pikes peak (14,110ft., or 14,115ft. lately) about half dozen times and i recognize the profile of the peak and its skyline. on top there is the cog train station, a meteo station and a few poles. from where i was (near mule deer entrance in ute valley park), the light was to the west. the white light (like that of a headlight) was significantly to the left of the peak, from my vantage point - that is, south of the peak. it was shaped like a horizontal segment. initially i thought that might be the landing lights of a plane, facing in our direction, though i have never seen anything like that, in that position (i live in the area for seven years and i have a view of pikes peak from home). the size was not right (it was way too large), given the apparent distance. the intensity of the light seemed way too much for a few headlights, even those of a plane, given the apparent distance to them. plus, the light was not moving, which was unusual if it came from a plane. the light seemed to might have moved slightly around, but remained approximately in the same position. initially, the light appeared like a stronger source of light, not circular or star-like, but more linear, oriented horizontally. it appeared larger than the apparent size of the cog train station, plus it was located clearly south of pikes peak (left of the peak, from my vantage point). the sky was quite bright, after the sunset, when we first noticed the light. initially, my friend thought it might be a star, but the light looked quite different from a twinkling star. it gradually looked more and more different than the point-like source of light (like stars are). the sky was also getting gradually darker. the light slowly appeared like the top sketch ("obs 1") shown in file attached. it was not a clear, big image, but that\'s how it appeared to me, after it started simpler, as a horizontally oriented, linear source of white light. about a couple of minutes later, the light appeared to me as shown in the second sketch ("obs 2") in the attached file. i was trying hard to explain away what i was seeing, but i could not, so i tried to observe the sight as well as i could. images in the attached file show what i saw with the naked eye. we rushed home - i wanted to grab a pair of binoculars - where we arrived at h17:50 mst. the snow and ice on the road slowed us down. as we were exiting ute valley park (towards mule deer drive) and losing elevation, the light disappeared below and behind the mountains \ pikes peak skyline. i grabbed two pairs of binoculars from home and rushed back to ute valley park. by this time (about h18:00 mst), the sky was dark and i saw no light in that particular region of the sky. i did see other stars in the sky, but no light like the one i have seen earlier. this sighting remains unexplained to me.
